questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most common type of facial nerve injury?
questions.explanation:
The most common type of nerve injury, in general, is neuropraxia. It is also true for facial nerve 
injury.

questions.question:
Question 2: You are a final-year student examining a patient with a right supranuclear facial palsy. Which 
of the following findings you will see?

options.a: Loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue
options.b: Paralysis of lower facial muscle on left side
options.c: Paralysis of lower facial nerve on right side
options.d: Loss of corneal reflex on left side

questions.explanation:
Right upper motor neuron (UMN) facial nerve palsy causes paralysis of lower facial muscles on 
the left side. The upper part of the facial nerve’s motor nucleus, which innervates forehead muscles, receives 
fibers from both the cerebral hemispheres. The lower part of the nucleus, which supplies the 
lower face, only receives crossed fibers from the contralateral hemisphere. Therefore, the upper 
part of the face gets bilateral innervation and the lower part of the face gets crossed innervation 
from the opposite side. Hence, in supranuclear lesion (UMN palsy), forehead is spared and muscles of the lower half of 
the opposite side of the face are affected. In LMN palsy, all muscles of the same side are affected. 229 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: While examining a patient with upper motor neuron facial nerve palsy, you notice emotional 
expressions such as smiling and crying are unaffected. How will you explain this?

options.d: Innervation by fibres from prefrontal cortex

questions.explanation:
The fibres from the thalamus are responsible for the involuntary movements of facial muscles in 
emotional states. These fibres reach the facial nerve nucleus via alternate pathways and are 
unaffected by UMN causes.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is the most common cause of LMN facial nerve palsy?
questions.explanation:
Bell’s palsy is the most common cause of LMN facial nerve palsy. It is defined as idiopathic, 
ipsilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. Causes of facial nerve palsy: 230

questions.question:
Question 5: A 35-year-old housewife presents with facial weakness on the right side, difficulty in closing 
the right eye, and loss of taste sensation. A diagnosis of Bell’s palsy is made. Which of the 
following is false regarding this condition?

options.d: Males are affected more commonly than females

questions.explanation:
Bell’s palsy affects both males and females equally. It is an acute onset idiopathic ipsilateral LMN 
facial nerve palsy. Most of the evidence supports the viral etiology due to herpes simplex, herpes zoster, or the 
Epstein–Barr virus. Positive family history is present in 6–8% of patients. Most of the patients recover fully and the 
remaining require surgery. Recurrent facial palsy is seen in 3–10% of cases.

questions.question:
Question 6: While examining a patient with LMN facial palsy, you observe Bell's phenomenon. In which 
direction would you expect the eyeball to move?
questions.explanation:
In Bell’s phenomenon, the eyeball turns upwards and outwards on the affected side while 
attempting to close the eyes. This phenomenon is seen in LMN facial palsy. The following image shows Bell's phenomenon. 231 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: You are an ENT resident examining a patient with Bell’s palsy. Which of the following 
findings is unlikely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ptosis is not seen in patients with Bell’s palsy. Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy: • Sudden onset • Bell's phenomenon • Asymmetrical face • Some may complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of 
chorda tympani). The following image shows a patient with Bell's palsy.

questions.question:
Question 8: 222 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with facial nerve palsy is intolerant to loud sounds. Involvement of which muscle 
will cause this?
questions.explanation:
Noise intolerance in a patient with facial nerve palsy is due to stapedius muscle paralysis. The stapedius muscle is supplied by the facial nerve via nerve to stapedius. It acts by dampening 
the loud sounds and the loss of this function results in hyperacusis. Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the eustachian tube, hence also called dilator tubae muscle. Tensor tympani, supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve, also helps in 
dampening the loud sounds. It is not involved in facial nerve palsy.

questions.question:
Question 9: In the evaluation of a patient with facial nerve palsy, what is the ideal time to do 
electroneuronography?
questions.explanation:
232 
Sold by @itachibot Electroneuronography is most useful when done between 4 and 21 days of the onset of complete 
paralysis. Degeneration of the nerve fibers cannot be detected earlier than 48–72 h of its commencement. 
Hence electrodiagnostic tests are done after 72 hours following injury.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 2nd year ENT resident is evaluating a patient with Bell’s palsy. Which of the following tests 
he will not do to identify the site of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Electromyography is not a topodiagnostic test used in facial palsy. It is used to monitor nerve 
degeneration in facial palsy. Topodiagnostic tests are done to identify the site of lesion in the intratemporal part of the facial 
nerve. They are: • Schirmer test - quantification of lacrimation • Stapedial reflex • Taste test by electrogustometry • Submandibular salivary flow test.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient with facial nerve palsy presented with dry eye. Injury to which part of the facial 
nerve will produce this symptom?
questions.explanation:
Injury at the level or proximal to the geniculate ganglion will produce dry eye due to decreased 
lacrimation. Geniculate ganglion gives the secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland via the greater superficial 
petrosal nerve.

questions.question:
Question 12: A middle-aged man presents with facial asymmetry. On examination, there is loss of taste 
from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, absent acoustic reflex, and normal Schirmer test. What is 
the site of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent 
acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment. Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the 
Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion. Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of 
stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry. Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is 
detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected 
by salivary flow test. So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, 
and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal. 233 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 30-year-old man presented with the following findings which he noticed when he woke up 
in the morning. There was no history of associated fever or rash. A panel of investigations was 
done and were found to be normal. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of 
this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy and statements 2,4 and 5 are false with 
respect to the treatment. Management of Bell's palsy: Steroids are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy. If the patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose 
of prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses for 5 days should be given. Steroids can be combined with acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus or if viral etiology is suspected in 
Bell's palsy. General measures include reassurance, physiotherapy, or massage of facial muscles, and care of 
the eye to prevent exposure keratitis. It includes artificial tears drops, eye ointment, and taping of 
eyes during the night. If the recovery is prolonged, temporary tarsorrhaphy is indicated. Surgical treatments like nerve decompression are done only when the medical management fails.

questions.question:
Question 14: 224 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following would you not expect to see in a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal 
syndrome?
questions.explanation: Cleft palate is not seen in a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of: • Facial paralysis • Swelling of lips and • Fissured tongue. The following image shows a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient with the following findings in the image comes to the OPD. What is the most likely 
causative agent for this condition?
questions.explanation:
234 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome and it is caused by the Herpes 
zoster virus. The image shows right-sided LMN facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external 
auditory canal and pinna which is a classical presentation of this syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 30-year-old woman presented with left-sided facial weakness. On examination, she has 
vesicles in the external auditory canal and over the tympanic membrane. Which of the 
following is false about this condition?

options.c: 8th cranial nerve may also be involved
options.d: Surgery is the mainstay of treatment

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with facial nerve palsy and vesicles in the external auditory canal is 
suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome (Herpes Zoster oticus). Surgery is not the mainstay of 
treatment. Steroids and antivirals are the mainstays of treatment. There may also be anesthesia of the face, giddiness, and hearing impairment due to the 
involvement of the 5th and 8th cranial nerves.

questions.question:
Question 17: An anxious woman presents to you with complaints of watering of the right eye while eating. 
She gives a history of transient facial weakness a few months back. Which of the following is 
the most likely cause for this condition?

options.a: Faulty regeneration of facial nerve fibres
options.b: Faulty regeneration of trigeminal nerve fibres
options.c: Faulty regeneration of vagal nerve fibres
options.d: Faulty regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is crocodile tear syndrome or Bogard syndrome (gustatory lacrimation) 
and is due to faulty regeneration of facial nerve fibres. It presents as unilateral lacrimation during 
eating and drinking. It is seen in cases where the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During 
regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland. It can be treated by section of the greater superficial petrosal nerve.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 50-year-old woman presented with sweating over the right cheek while eating. She 
underwent parotid surgery 6 months back. The finding of the starch iodine test is shown in 
the image. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?

options.a: Aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic
options.b: Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with greater auricular nerve
options.c: Aberrant reinnervation of sympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with parasympathetic
options.d: Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with auriculotemporal nerve

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is Frey’s syndrome or gustatory sweating. It is due to aberrant 
reinnervation (or cross innervation) of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve 
(which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands. The patient usually presents with sweating and flushing over the parotid area during 
mastication. This usually occurs after parotid surgery. It is diagnosed by Minor's test or starch iodine test. The affected area is painted with iodine and is 
allowed to dry. Then dry corn starch is applied. The starch turns blue on exposure to iodine in the 
presence of sweat.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is the most common cause of hemifacial spasm?
questions.explanation:
A vascular loop abutting the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle is the most common cause 
of hemifacial spasm. This usually presents as a unilateral involuntary uncontrollable twitching of 
the face. 235 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment is microvascular decompression or removal of any other inciting cause like acoustic 
neuroma, congenital cholesteatoma, glomus tumor. In refractory cases, botulinum toxin and 
selective nerve sectioning are done.

questions.question: Question 20: Which temporal bone fracture is most commonly associated with facial nerve palsy?
questions.explanation:
The transverse fracture of the petrous temporal bone is most commonly associated with facial 
nerve palsy.

questions.question:
Question 21: Following a blow to the head by a metal rod during a gang fight, a patient presented with 
clear watery discharge from the ear. The discharge is positive for beta-2 transferrin. Which of 
the following is the most likely cause for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF otorrhea and it is seen in longitudinal fracture of 
the petrous part of the temporal bone. The transverse fracture of petrous temporal bone and fracture of cribriform plate leads to CSF 
rhinorrhea. 236 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: You suspect a temporal bone fracture in a patient who presented with right side facial 
weakness, decreased hearing, vertigo, and bleeding from the ear. What is the investigation of 227 
Sold by @itachibot choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
HRCT (High-resolution CT) is the investigation of choice for the temporal bone fractures 
complicated by facial nerve palsy or CSF leak. 237 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: An intern is assisting the surgeon in total parotidectomy. During the procedure, he 
accidentally injured the facial nerve. Which of the following cannot be used as a graft for 
repair in this case?
questions.explanation:
The mandibular nerve cannot be used as a graft for facial nerve surgeries. Only those nerves whose functions can be sacrificed are chosen as grafts and these are usually 
sensory nerves. The most commonly used grafts for facial nerve are: • Greater auricular nerve (can be extracted from the same incision) • Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh • Sural nerve (when a large segment is required). 238 
Sold by @itachibot Eustachian Tube
